Background

Prions are PROteinaceuous INfectious particles, that is infectious particles that consist purely of protein. It is now generally accepted that they are the causative agents in several neurodegenerative diseases of mammals, including BSE in cattle, scrapie in sheep and CJD in humans. Proteins with similar properties have also been found in the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, though in contrast to the mammalian prions, yeast prions are not necessarily detrimental to the host organism.

 

Prions are an abnormal form of a protein that occurs naturally in the organism. Most of our work is concerned with the yeast prion [PSI], where the underlying protein is the translation termination factor Sup35p. Cells containing the prion form of the protein are denoted [PSI+] while those that are prion-free are [psi-]

 

The [PSI+] strain of Saccharomyces cerevisiae was discovered in 1964 by Brian Cox, with whom we have had many productive discussions during this project. However, it was not until 1994 that Reed Wickner first suggested that [PSI+] might be a prion strain.

Reed Wickner
Brian Cox
